title: 103_hr3408
content: The text highlights the cultural significance of New Orleans as the birthplace of jazz and the establishment of Jean Lafitte National Historical Park to commemorate the cultural diversity of the region, including jazz. The purpose of the Act is to establish a New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park and associated educational programs. The New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park, part of the Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve, aims to preserve the origins and early history of jazz, provide opportunities for visitors to experience where jazz evolved, and establish educational partnerships to ensure jazz remains a vital cultural element in New Orleans and the nation. The New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park is established as part of the Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve to preserve the origins and early history of jazz, provide opportunities for visitors to experience where jazz evolved, and establish educational partnerships to ensure jazz remains a vital cultural element in New Orleans and the nation. The New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park is established to preserve, educate, and interpret jazz history in New Orleans. It is administered as part of the Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve, focusing on the lower Mississippi Delta Region. The historical park includes lands designated for an interpretive visitor center complex and sites under cooperative agreements. The New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park preserves jazz history in New Orleans through interpretive programs at sites under cooperative agreements with the National Park Service. The Secretary is directed to evaluate sites associated with jazz in and around New Orleans for potential designation as National Historic Landmarks. The Secretary may designate sites associated with jazz in New Orleans as part of the historical park, following consultation with relevant parties and notification to congressional committees. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATION. The Secretary administers the historical park in accordance with relevant laws and manages it to preserve the history of jazz. Donations of funds, property, or services can be accepted for park purposes. The Secretary is authorized to lease, construct, operate, or maintain an interpretive center in New Orleans for jazz-related programs. The Secretary may also provide technical assistance for the designation of jazz heritage districts in and around New Orleans. The Secretary can enter cooperative agreements with property owners in New Orleans for educational opportunities related to jazz evolution. Assistance may be provided for rehabilitation, restoration, marking, and interpretation of properties designated under the Act. The agreements may include provisions for National Park Service access and compliance with the Secretary's standards. The Secretary can enter cooperative agreements with the city of New Orleans and other organizations for the acquisition, construction, and operation of interpretive centers. Grants and technical assistance can be provided to public and private organizations for jazz educational programs. The Secretary will promote educational activities related to jazz and its history at the historical park, collaborating with schools, universities, and organizations supporting jazz education to enhance public understanding and appreciation. Assistance may be provided in developing an information base with archival material, audiovisual records, and objects related to jazz history. SEC. 5. ACQUISITION OF PROPERTY. The Secretary can acquire lands within designated sites by donation or purchase with funds. State and local properties in Louisiana can only be acquired by donation. SEC. 6. GENERAL MANAGEMENT PLAN. Within 3 years of funds availability, the Secretary, in consultation with the New Orleans Jazz Commission, will prepare a general management plan for the historical park. The plan will include a visitor use plan, preservation and use plans for structures and sites, location and cost of public facilities, and identification of programs. The Secretary, in consultation with the New Orleans Jazz Commission, will prepare a general management plan for the historical park within 3 years of funds availability. The plan will include a transportation plan, archival system implementation, and guidelines for cooperative agreements. Establishment of the New Orleans Jazz Commission. The New Orleans Jazz Commission is established to assist in implementing the purposes of the Act and the New Orleans Jazz Special Resource Study. It consists of 15 members appointed by the Secretary, including individuals with experience in music education programs, tourism in the New Orleans area, and historic preservation. The New Orleans Jazz Commission consists of 15 members appointed by the Secretary, including individuals with experience in music education programs, tourism in the New Orleans area, and historic preservation. The commission includes members with expertise in historic preservation, musicians with knowledge of jazz development, folklore preservation, local neighborhood groups, social clubs, and the Louisiana State Music Commission. The New Orleans Jazz Commission, consisting of 15 members appointed by the Secretary, advises on the preparation of the historical park's management plan, develops partnerships with educational groups, and works with individuals and organizations to determine programs through cooperative agreements. The New Orleans Jazz Commission, in consultation with the Secretary, develops partnerships with citywide organizations to raise funds for jazz cultural traditions, acquire property for jazz education, provide recommendations for visitor center locations, support research on jazz origins, and seek funding opportunities. The New Orleans Jazz Commission can seek donations and use them for jazz education programs and historic landmark restoration. Commission members serve staggered 3-year terms and elect a chairman for a 3-year term. The chairman of the Commission serves for 3 years and is an ex officio member of the Delta Regional Preservation Commission. Members can serve after their term until a successor is appointed. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members serve without compensation but are entitled to travel expenses. The Secretary provides administrative support. The Commission receives administrative support from the Secretary to obtain personnel, equipment, and facilities. They must submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing expenses, income, grants, and technical assistance provided. SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS: Sums may be appropriated as needed for this Act.
